) Cases are controlled in multiple automated systems, including AIMS, ACDS, CATS, CDPTS, ISTS, PACER, and AOIC. (
) Cases are established, updated and closed using the following systems: (cid:
) ACDS (Appeals Centralized Database System) (cid:
) AIMS (Audit Information Management System) (cid:
) IDRS (Integrated Data Retrieval System) (cid:
) CDPTS (Collection Due Process Tracking System). (cid:
) ISTS (Innocent Spouse Tracking System). (
) The following systems provide additional research information on cases handled by Appeals: (cid:
) CATS (Counsel Automated Tracking System) (cid:
) PACER (Public Access to Court Electronic Records (cid:
) AOIC (Automated Offer in Compromise System). (

) Generally, Account and Processing Support (APS) uses the systems to establish, maintain and close cases in Appeals. However, all Appeals employees have an interest in the information on some of the systems. following subsections briefly describe the more commonly used systems. (
) Appeals receives some cases from Compliance which may be controlled AIMS. These cases may have been audited for possible additional tax penalty liabilities. See IRM
, AIMS Procedures and Processing for information relating to AIMS processing of examination returns. Also Document

) Each AIMS input form is identified by a number or a command code, as explained in text below. The Audit Information Management Systems contains instructions and screen examples for all AIMS input codes. The terminal operator uses the command code to tell the terminal what is being input and how the data file should treat the information. Internal Revenue Manual

) Workcenter functionality includes occupation related personal inventory systems, timekeeping, reports, inventory updates, forms and letter and electronic notification. (

) ACDS is a relational database management system incorporating various employee modules into a single integrated database model eliminating duplicate entry, maximizing security functionality and consolidating tive tasks and duties into one system. (
) ACDS is used for all Appeals management statistics and produces ment information reports. (
) The following are some of the functions available to all ACDS users: (cid:
) Home — This returns the user to the ACDS home page. It identifies home area in relationship to the Field Areas. (cid:
) ACDS Memos — Contains ACDS MEMOS issued. (cid:
) SEARCH — This allows an employee access to search the ACDS open closed database using various options i.e. TIN, TPName, docket WUNO, etc.

) To accomplish the Appeals mission, it is essential taxpayers have a prompt and independent review when they disagree with the changes proposed by Compliance. Settling and (

) Appeals provides the final administrative opportunity to the taxpayer and Appeals Service to resolve tax disputes fairly and without litigation. It is essential Appeals command the respect and trust of taxpayers and practitioners. One aspect of this activity is presenting a unified Appeals position to taxpayers and/or practitioners when settling an issue. See IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (
) Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) is an umbrella term used to refer to Appeals employees in the various technical positions. See IRM
for a list of positions. (
) Account and Processing Support (APS) employees play an active role in cessing the cases received in Appeals. (
) Information pertaining to the role of management can be found in IRM Appeals Managers Procedures. (

) An Appeals Officer (AO) works cases with issues ranging from the simplest the most complex, and from few to millions of dollars. To successfully (AO) plish this, they must: a. exhibit confidence in their job knowledge; b. act responsibly; c. display a judicial attitude when applying tax law in a reasonable and impartial manner; d. strive for uniformity and consistency with respect to taxpayers in similar circumstances and achieving the primary goal of resolving the dispute; e. conduct conferences in a courteous manner which provides an atmo- sphere of openness and fosters cooperation in the resolution of f. be a good listener. (

) In cases where the AO and the taxpayer succeed in reaching agreement it important all aspects of the case be fully discussed so all parties the issue(s), particularly when agreement is based on hazards of litigation. (

) However, when a satisfactory basis of settlement cannot be reached, the must explain the procedural rights of appeal to the extent necessary to taxpayers and representatives understand these rights. (
) An AO meets with people from all walks of life whose trust must be earned satisfactory dealings are to be accomplished. (

Appeals (

) Experience has shown, when an AO is able to enlist the cooperation of taxpayers and representatives, cases are resolved on a mutually basis with minimum expense, delay, and inconvenience to taxpayers. (

) The Appeals Team Case Leader primarily works Coordinated Industry (CIC). These cases contain high dollar amounts and very complex issues. Team Case Most of these cases are worked in a team format. (ATCL) (

) The ATCL leads Appeals Officers, technicians, and other support personnel working team cases. They are responsible for planning the team’s work into consideration any organizational priorities and necessities. (

) It is important the ATCL ensure the work is completed in a timely manner. she does this by assigning team work, monitoring team members’ progress assignments, and personally working a variety of the most demanding case issues. If there are problems, the ATCL takes immediate corrective so there is no adverse impact on resolving the case. (

) The ATCL provides feedback to team member and his/her immediate and serves as a mentor and coach to team members to enhance their mance and settlement skills. The feedback is both written and oral; on a timely and ongoing basis; and addresses the appropriate critical job elements and aspects. When necessary the ATCL apprises management of critical or sensitive work related matters. (

) While the case is in Appeals, the ATCL prepares and updates work plans including directing team members to insure the progression of the case overseeing the team members during the settlement conferences and/or meetings with the largest corporate taxpayers and their representatives, Counsel and other employees of the Service. (

) The ATCL exercises overall responsibility for arriving at the final disposition the work unit from the Government’s perspective including authority to recommendations made by team members on the settlement of their issues, and to approve the final settlement. (
) The Settlement Officer (SO) is primarily responsible for administratively resolving disputes in collection cases. This may include but is not limited Officer (SO) (cid:
) Collection Due Process (CDP) (cid:
) Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) (cid:
) Collection Appeals Program (CAP) (cid:
) Offer in Compromise (OIC) (

) The SO consideration addresses and affects the interests of a wide range taxpayers and their representatives including individuals whose only wages and/or investments, sole proprietors, and individuals with business supplemental income. (
) SO decisions may have a decisive and lasting influence upon the circumstances of taxpayers and may have an impact on the taxpayer’s interests in subsequent years. (
) The SO uses the Appeals Officer skills outlined in IRM
) above takes timely initial and follow-up actions while keeping taxpayers informed the status of their case and avoiding prohibited ex parte communication. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
J

) The Appeals Tax Specialist (ATS) position is generally centralized in an Appeals Campus location. (
) The ATS handles the following types of cases which may involve an Appeals conference: a. Campus generated Post-assessment Penalty Appeals (PENAP), and b. Barred statute claims. (
) The ATS uses the skills outlined in IRM
, Appeals Officer. (

) The Appeals Account Resolution Specialists (AARS) work the Appeals Customer Service line handling inquiries for every type of case; open, signed, assigned, closed, and not yet in Appeals. The line is available to internal and external Appeals customers including: (cid:
) Taxpayers (cid:
) Representatives (cid:
) Appeals employees (cid:
) IRS employees (cid:
) TAS employees (

) In addition to servicing customers on the Appeals Customer Service line, AARS receive Back End Account Resolution Referrals to resolve account problems on closed Appeals cases. Closed case referrals are received the Customer Service line, TAS, IRS employees, or other Appeals For Appeals employees, the “Back End Account Resolution Referral” form found on APGolf can be emailed to *AP Account Resolution or faxed. All customers should call the Appeals Customer Service line for direction. examples of the types of problems the Back End Account Resolution handle are: a. Innocent Spouse allocations, which includes the mirroring process b. Tax Court Decision application c. Misapplied/Missing payment research d. Installment Agreements which include Direct Debit Installment and Partial Payment Installment Agreement e. Currently Not Collectible issues f. Erroneous Refunds g. Levy/Lien issues h. Offer in Compromise processing i. Excess Collection issues j. Account Freezes k. Correction of Unpostable Transaction Codes l. Processing of Form
m. Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Issues. (

) Actions related to open cases (cid:
) Closed case inquiries when the taxpayer and/or POA is not in with the decisions (cid:

) Generally the AARS analyzes taxpayer responses and initiates further to identify potential liability and to provide technical and procedural to taxpayers and the taxpayer’s representative by correspondence, and in person. (
) The AARS researches and analyzes several automated and manual to find necessary information, such as: a. compliance history; b. statute suspensions; and c. financial information. (
) The AARS will often initiate adjustments on tax accounts to ensure proper sessments, application of payments, and to resolve disputes between Compliance and the taxpayer. (

) Specialty Operations, which includes Domestic Operations and International Operations, ensures nationwide uniform and consistent settlement of enhances the identification and timely resolution of issues, and provides a vehicle for coordination of technical issues. (

) The Technical Specialist provides coordination and expertise to Appeals agement and ATEs in the following areas: a. Compliance coordinated issues (CCI) b. Appeals coordinated issues (ACI) c. Emerging issues (EM) d. Abusive Corporate Tax Shelters e. Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions f. Engineering Issues g. Financial Products Issues (
) In order to develop issue experts who are available to assist ATEs in the settlement of their cases, the Technical Specialist: (cid:
) Serves as the focal point for activities involving issues in the industry or specialty area by providing continual advice, guidance, and assistance ATEs; (cid:

) Develops and maintains expertise on both coordinated and emerging issues. Technical Specialists are constantly researching their specialty maintain expertise in technically and factually complicated issues. (cid:
) Provides research information and timely litigation updates to ATEs; (cid:
) Provides technical guidance/expertise and support to ATEs. (cid:
) Provides guidance on issues in their industries or specialty areas which not officially coordinated in Specialty Operations; (cid:
) Trains others in his or her field of expertise (classroom, IVT, CPEs etc.); (cid:
) Attends both internal and external training seminars and other courses; (cid:
) Participates as team members (TM) or consultants on Appeals cases; (cid:

); (cid:

) It is important for the ATE to involve the Technical Specialist early in the and to continue to include the Technical Specialist throughout the case. there’s open communication throughout the settlement process, it’s less there will be unanswered questions during the R&C process. (
) Similar to the functions of Technical Specialists, Economists and Engineers provide coordination and expertise to Appeals management and ATEs on issues. (
) Economists and Engineers are assigned to cases as consultants or team members. (

) This section provides an overview of the role and responsibility of the Tax Computation Specialist (TCS) and the important assistance they the Appeals Technical employees and Account and Processing Support employees. (
) The TCS organization reports to the Director, Technical Support. The Policy, Quality and Case Support manages the Technical Support (

) TCS is comprised of TCS Teams, each supervised by an Appeals Tax tation Team Manager (ATCTM). Each team may consist of one or more Case Tax Computation Specialists, Senior Tax Computation Specialists and Tax Computation Specialists. (

) In addition to their other responsibilities, the Tax Computation Specialist prepares the following: a. settlement computations, b. notices, c. tentative computations, d. information statements, and e. other analyses. (
) The TCS provides valuable services which relieve the ATE and APS of time- consuming, detailed computational/technical analysis so more time is to the settlement or processing of disputed cases. (

) In order to properly aid the ATE or APS, the TCS must: a. examine the case file and analyze the examining officer’s report. b. be familiar with all areas of tax law and regulations (individual, estate, gift, employment, etc.). c. have a sound foundation in accounting principles. d. have a good knowledge of IRS procedures and operations. e. be able to apply all of the above to the technical work.
(cid:
) Promotes consistency in settlements in Appeals, either traditionally or via ADR processes such as Fast Track Settlement (FTS), Fast Track Mediation (FTM) or Post Appeals Mediation. (cid:
) Determines the Hazards of Litigation (HOL) - factual, legal or combination of both.

It is important for the ATE to involve the Technical Specialist early in the case and to continue to include the Technical Specialist throughout the case. When there’s open communication throughout the settlement process, it’s less likely there will be unanswered questions during the R&C process.
The TCS organization reports to the Director, Technical Support. The Director, Policy, Quality and Case Support manages the Technical Support organization.

) The TCS makes technical and accounting analyses in tax cases, including protested and/or petitioned Joint Committee cases with overpayments of $
In addition, they may be assigned selected cases for and disposition in their capacity of an acting AO. (

) The Large Case Tax Computation Specialist may appear as the expert witness giving testimony in court proceedings on the tax effect of con- troversial tax adjustments in complex corporate tax cases. (

) Account and Processing Support (APS) provides technical assistance and support for controlling and processing tax cases for Appeals and Counsel. It the final processing point in the Appeals Office and performs the full range of interim and closing actions which includes the following: a. Verify contents of the administrative file b. Update or make corrections on IDRS, ACDS, AIMS, and ISTS c. Process interim assessments or abatements d. Control statutes e. Issue notices of deficiencies (SND or

-day letter), determination interest abatement letters, EP and EO Adverse determinations or other required notices or correspondence f. Process cases resolved by the Appeals Officers and/or Counsel. This includes processing assessments, adjustments, installment agreements and offers-in-compromise g. Process cases between Appeals and Counsel. (
) The following provides a brief description of the employees in the APS zation and their role: (cid:

) Director, Account and Processing Support, is responsible for the overall ganization including staffing and directing case processing activities. The APS Director is the first level supervisor of the APS Area Managers and second level supervisor of the APS Processing Team Managers. (cid:

) The APS Area Manager is responsible for planning, organizing, ing, monitoring and directing the activities of a work force in APS units in their Area. The APS Area Manager is the first level supervisor of the APS Processing Team Manager and the second level supervisor of the APS employees. (cid:
) APS Technical Advisors assist either the Director, Account and Support or the APS Area Manager, in the daily operations of the Area or APS organization. (cid:
) APS Processing Team Managers (PTM) direct the activities performed by the APS employees. They are the first level supervisor of APS (cid:

) APS Tax Examiners (TEs) process a full range of cases in accordance established procedures. The TEs receive and review administrative files, create and update automated systems, prepare and make interim and adjustments, determine statute of limitations on a wide variety of tax and compute interest. (cid:
) Case Processors provide administrative, clerical, and technical support within the Appeals office. (cid:

) The secretary may be assigned to assist any APS manager. The may work for an Appeals Team Manager but in addition, assist an APS Manager. They may assist in preparing correspondence, evaluations, keeping, updating automated systems, and assisting in the case work. Internal Revenue Manual
